com.datastax.oss.driver.api.core.session.throttling

Interface RequestThrottler

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AutoCloseable, Closeable

    public interface RequestThrottler
extends Closeable
    Limits the number of concurrent requests executed by the driver.

    Usage in non-blocking applications: beware that all built-in implementations of this interface use locks for internal coordination, and do not qualify as lock-free, with the obvious exception of PassThroughRequestThrottler. If your application enforces strict lock-freedom, then request throttling should not be enabled.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void register(Throttled request)
      Registers a new request to be throttled.
      void signalError(Throttled request, Throwable error)
      Signals that a request has failed.
      void signalSuccess(Throttled request)

      void signalTimeout(Throttled request)
      Signals that a request has timed out.

      • Methods inherited from interface java.io.Closeable

        close

    • Method Detail

      • register

        void register(@NonNull
              Throttled request)
        Registers a new request to be throttled. The throttler will invoke Throttled.onThrottleReady(boolean) when the request is allowed to proceed.

      • signalSuccess

        void signalSuccess(@NonNull
                   Throttled request)
        Signals that a request has succeeded. This indicates to the throttler that another request might be started.

      • signalError

        void signalError(@NonNull
                 Throttled request,
                 @NonNull
                 Throwable error)
        Signals that a request has failed. This indicates to the throttler that another request might be started.

      • signalTimeout

        void signalTimeout(@NonNull
                   Throttled request)
        Signals that a request has timed out. This indicates to the throttler that this request has stopped (if it was running already), or that it doesn't need to be started in the future.

        Note: requests are responsible for handling their own timeout. The throttler does not perform time-based eviction on pending requests.
